utterance_text: Well, my wife has been urging me a lot lately to improve my health habits. I'm not sure what the issue is because I've been working really hard. Sometimes I can't make it home for dinner and end up eating out at places like Applebee's. But she seems more concerned than I am—I just don't see why there's such a fuss.
It sounds like you're feeling that your health isn't something to worry about right now, is that correct?
Yes, I feel fine.
Understood.
My job involves a lot of manual labor, so I'm usually working outside in the heat and sweating it all out. That helps me deal with anything unhealthy I might consume.
Have you noticed any changes in your weight or anything similar?
A little bit, but nothing significant. I don't feel bloated at all.
Got it. And have you had a recent check-up with your doctor?
Yes, I went for a physical last year and everything was fine.
So, you're feeling good overall?
Yes, I am.
It seems like you think your wife might be more concerned than necessary about this situation. Is that right?
Not exactly overreacting—I know she cares and wants me to live a long, healthy life. But sometimes, especially with a demanding job, eating out can feel comforting.
I understand. If it's okay with you, I'd like to share some information about obesity or diabetes, just in case you're interested.
Sure. [unintelligible 00:01:33]
Great, thank you.
Sarah, I'm glad you came for your well-woman exam today. We've covered a lot of ground regarding your concerns. May we discuss your smoking habits further?
Sure, that's fine.
Could you tell me more about how often you smoke in a day? You mentioned it has increased from once or twice daily.
Yeah, typically I smoke once in the morning, once during lunch, and then maybe five or six times in the evening.
So that's around eight cigarettes per day. Would that be just under half a pack?
Yes, that sounds about right.
Over what period has this increase occurred?
Honestly, it's probably been over the past year that I've started smoking more.
So your smoking has increased over the last year, particularly in the evening?
Yeah. Since my two-year-old son is around, I try to avoid smoking when he's awake and usually wait until he goes to bed.
That makes sense; it seems like a time for you to relax and unwind.
Exactly. With your busy schedule—working full-time and attending night classes—I understand why the evening feels like a personal time for relaxation.
Of course, that's an important time for you given everything on your plate.
Yes, it is.
What other activities do you engage in during the evenings to relax?
Sometimes I might have one or two drinks.
One or two drinks. How many would you typically have over a week?
I'm not sure why we're discussing this; I thought today was just for my regular check-up, and I don't see myself as someone who needs to talk about drinking.

I understand, Sarah. My intention isn't to dictate your choices but rather to share information that might be helpful given your busy life as a mother, worker, and student. Our healthcare team wants to ensure you have the resources needed for your health goals. Would it be okay if we discuss some health concerns related to smoking and alcohol?
Okay, I suppose.

We know increased smoking and drinking can be linked to various cancers—like colon, cervical, breast, lung, and pancreatic cancer—as well as liver, lung diseases, heart disease, diabetes, and hypertension. It's a lot of information, but I'm interested in hearing your thoughts on this.
Well, I don't smoke or drink that much compared to others at work. I've been trying to keep it low.
So you're making an effort to reduce your intake?
Yes, I am.
Here's a readiness ruler in my pocket; 0 means not ready to quit smoking at all, and 10 means completely ready. Where do you see yourself on this scale?
Maybe around five.
About halfway there. What makes you choose five instead of four?
The risks you mentioned, like cancer, are concerning, especially as a mother. I don't want anything to happen to me.
That's understandable. Considering these health concerns and your family worries, where do you stand in thinking about making changes? What steps might move you closer to a 10?
Perhaps I could try cutting back on smoking in the evenings a bit.
Great idea. How many cigarettes would that be?
If I'm currently smoking five or six in the evening, maybe three plus what I smoke during the day.
That's quite a reduction. Since our time is limited today, would you consider coming back in about four weeks to review this plan?
Sure, that works for me.
Excellent. We can discuss your lab results and your progress then. Would you like some information on smoking cessation?
Yes, I think that would be helpful.
Here's a brochure with useful distraction techniques for nicotine cravings—it has helped other patients before. Additionally, would you consider meeting one of our counselors?
What exactly would they discuss?

Dr. Kirtley specializes in the relationship between alcohol and stress. The National Guidelines suggest women should have no more than seven drinks per week to minimize health risks. Since your drinking is a bit higher, it might be beneficial to talk with him.
I'm open to discussing my stress, but I'm still unsure about addressing my drinking habits.

That's perfectly fine. I'm glad you're willing to speak with Dr. Kirtley. Before you leave today, we'll arrange your follow-up appointment and a session with Dr. Kirtley at the scheduler’s desk. Do you have any other questions for me?
No, I think that covers everything.
Wonderful. It was nice meeting you, Sarah. See you in a month.
Okay.
Hi, Sal. Thank you for joining me today.
No problem at all.
I noticed your doctor referred you here, and I truly appreciate your effort in making this appointment.
Yeah, it's a bit inconvenient, but I'm here nonetheless.
You made the effort to come—do you have an understanding of what concerns led your doctor to refer you?
Something about needing more changes. The smoking has changed, and now there’s talk about reducing drinking, getting rid of extra cigarettes, and even my dog. I’m not sure what else is expected.
So it seems like your asthma issues are part of a broader set of challenges?
Yes, there's also a lot of stress. My wife is on unpaid maternity leave with the baby, so I'm the sole earner. Plus, I need to make these life changes.
It sounds like you're dealing with quite a bit right now.
Absolutely, it feels overwhelming.
We have about 15 or 20 minutes together. Would it be alright if we took some time to explore the various challenges you’re facing and identify what might be most helpful for us to focus on?
Sure, everything seems scattered, but I guess we need a starting point.

One tool we use is an agenda-setting worksheet. If you could list all the changes others suggest or expect from you, what would they include? Remember, Sal, just because we write them down doesn’t mean you have to change anything—you’re in control here.
Okay.
It's simply a way to lay everything out on the table.
Alright. As long as I'm not committing to changes and it’s more about listing things—like putting pen to paper.
Exactly.
So, my asthma is one issue.
Got it, asthma is one concern. What else?
They also want me to get rid of Oscar, my dog.
Your doctor mentioned your dog as—
Yes, they say he's a major contributor to my asthma issues. I don't agree with that and can’t just give him up, but it’s something on the table.
That must be quite shocking to hear you need to part with your dog.
Definitely. He’s been in my life longer than my wife has.
Hmm. So this is causing significant stress for you?
Yes, he's like a best friend and very important to me. Also, I'm trying to quit smoking completely.
So quitting smoking is another goal of yours?
Finances are also a concern right now.
Okay, so money issues as well.
And time management—I have all these appointments and need to take time off work, which affects my finances too.
Right. The financial aspect ties into the time you spend on appointments.
Exactly. There’s a lot happening. I also need to reduce my drinking.
Wow, that's quite a bit going on right now, Sal. Is there anything else troubling you?
No, it just feels overwhelming when you see everything laid out like this.
Understandable. If you had to choose one or two high-priority areas to discuss today, where would you start?
The situation with my dog has been particularly distressing, and my asthma is also unmanageable. Maybe we can focus on those first.
Okay, it seems these issues are interconnected.
Yes, they are related in some ways.
Hello, how can I assist you today?

Yes, hopefully. Um, my workplace has just implemented a smoke-free policy. I'm not thrilled about it. I plan to continue smoking and was wondering if there's anything that could help me manage the day better. It's like going out for a beer and smoking after work.
So your workplace has become smoke-free, and you're feeling quite unhappy about it?
Yes, I don't intend to quit smoking. I enjoy it because it helps me relax. Honestly, I don’t see why there’s such an issue with it.
Could you share a bit more about how smoking fits into your daily routine? It might help us explore some options—
Well, I smoke just under a pack each day. It's manageable for me. I've been smoking for the past five years, and while I could quit if I wanted to, I'm not interested in doing so right now.
So it sounds like smoking is an important part of your life at this moment, and you're not ready to change that habit. However, you feel confident that you could quit if the decision came up?
Yes, I believe I can quit.
What gives you such confidence in quitting?
Well, I don't see why I couldn’t, although I've never tried before. It's just something I do for enjoyment, like during breaks at work or after finishing my day.

And regarding your readiness to actually make a quit attempt, where would you place yourself on a scale from 1 to 10? One being not considering it at all and ten being fully ready and wanting to quit?
I’d say about a two. I haven’t really thought about quitting until this new policy was announced today, so I’m definitely not planning to stop smoking.
What made you choose two instead of one?
Well, anything's possible, right? I suppose there’s a chance I could be persuaded. Are there things I can try that might make me want to quit smoking?

There are several products available now that can help reduce the urge to smoke. We have options that replace nicotine and decrease withdrawal symptoms when you cut down or quit, as well as medications your doctor could prescribe to lessen the desire to smoke.
That’s good to know. I’m not planning on doing anything today, but it's helpful to understand my options. If I decided to quit, at least I have some tools that might help me.
Absolutely. Considering you mentioned a two on the scale, what do you think would be needed for you to move up to a four or five?
I’m not sure. Maybe if one of my friends decided to quit with me, it could help. But all my friends enjoy smoking too, so that doesn’t seem likely soon.
It’s interesting to consider whether some colleagues at work might also be planning to quit now that the workplace is smoke-free.
That's a good point. I hadn't thought about that. Yes, it could be helpful.
It seems like you're here primarily for information today. I'm glad to help you explore these options when and if you decide it’s time for you.
Okay, thank you very much.
Hello, Laura.
Hi.
Thank you for joining me today. I'm curious if you're familiar with what we'll be discussing here. If it's alright, I'd like to give you a brief overview of our session.
Sure.

Essentially, we'll spend some time talking about your life goals and getting to know you better. We'll also discuss any behaviors you might want to explore changing. My role isn't to judge or change you but rather to understand how things are going for you, identify any changes you'd like to make, and see how I can support you in achieving what's most beneficial for you.
Okay.
Does that sound good?
Yes.
Great. To start off, could you tell me a bit about yourself?
My name is Laura. I'm 17 years old and a senior in high school.
Thank you for sharing. What are your plans or goals for the future?
Hopefully to attend college and maintain good grades to get accepted.
That sounds wonderful. Do you have any specific colleges in mind, perhaps locally or out of state?
I'm not certain yet, but I'm considering a few local schools and possibly applying to some out-of-state ones as well.
Interesting. So you're keeping your options open. What about your field of study—are there any particular areas you're interested in pursuing?
Maybe pre-law.
That's exciting! What do you enjoy doing for fun, Laura?
On weekends, I like to hang out with friends, go to parties or the mall, and attend school events like football games.
It sounds like you have a good time. Would you say you have many friends or just a few close ones?
Probably a moderate number—I'm not particularly popular, but I'm also not friendless.
That's perfectly fine. Being "normal" is great too! How are your grades currently?
They're pretty good—mostly As and Bs.

Excellent. Now, different people value different things in life, like family or friendships. Here’s a list of values such as belonging, community, cultural identity, family, friendship, modesty, religion, respect, self-determination, and spirituality. Which ones resonate with you?
Family is definitely important to me, along with friendship and belonging.
That makes sense. Can you tell me more about why your family is so significant to you?
I love them deeply and want them to think well of me, as well as feel accepting and loving towards me.
Do you have any siblings?
Yes, I have one sister.
Great. And what makes friendship important for you?
I've grown close to many people whom I care about, so being accepted by them is important too.
So having good friends and being a good friend yourself matters a lot. What about belonging—why do you find that significant?
It's about fitting in and feeling generally accepted.
You want to feel part of a group. Let’s talk about your social life a bit more. When you go out with friends, especially at parties, do you ever drink alcohol?
Not much—maybe one or two drinks at most.
Could you elaborate on how alcohol fits into your social interactions?
I usually have a drink just to appear like I'm drinking, so people don't pressure me about it.
So there's some peer pressure involved, and having a drink makes things easier for you. How often do these situations occur—like one or two weekends a month?
Yes, that sounds right.
And what kind of settings are these usually in?
Typically at parties or small gatherings where there might be some alcohol around.
So it's mostly about hanging out with friends. Are these places where parents are present, or is it just among peers?
Mostly just us kids, but sometimes I'm at a friend’s house where their family is also around.
And what about driving after drinking—do you ever find yourself in that situation?
No, I've never driven drunk nor been with someone who was. It's too dangerous.
That's very wise of you. What do you know about the dangers of drunk driving?
Alcohol impairs judgment and can lead to accidents, so it’s best avoided.
You're being very cautious, which is commendable. Can you tell me how many drinks you've had in one day at most?
Not more than two.
What do you like about alcohol when you do have it?
I haven't been drunk enough to know if I enjoy that feeling, but it does make people feel relaxed and good.
So it helps with relaxation. Are there any downsides to drinking for you?
Yes, at parties, some people drink too much and end up throwing up or acting obnoxiously, which isn't fun.
You've seen the negative consequences others face. How does alcohol fit into your life considering it's illegal for someone under 21?
It is risky, but many still do it.
Given that you value family and friendships, how does alcohol play a role in these areas of your life?
My parents don't approve of drinking, so it doesn’t fit with my family. But among friends at parties, alcohol is usually present.
So from your family's perspective, drinking isn't aligned with their values. With friends, do you feel like it helps you connect or have fun?
It seems to be part of the social scene and fits with feeling a sense of belonging.
Looking ahead 5 to 10 years, how do you see alcohol fitting into your life then?
I think its role will diminish significantly as I focus on my future goals like college and law school.
So drinking might interfere with reaching those goals. How often do you imagine yourself drinking when you're in college?
Probably even less than now—maybe just one drink occasionally.
It sounds like you have a plan to reduce your drinking over time. How important is it for you to make these adjustments, on a scale from 1 to 10?
Maybe around five or six.
Why did you choose that number instead of lower?
Because while it's not something I'm constantly thinking about changing, it’s still significant enough to consider.
And how confident are you in your ability to make these changes if you decide to do so?
Quite confident—I’m not really into drinking much anyway.
On a scale of 1 to 10, how would you rate your confidence in being able to quit or reduce drinking?
Probably an eight or nine because it's not a major part of my life.
It sounds like you have a plan to adjust your drinking habits and that it’s moderately important for you. What goal could we set for today?
I might try not having any drinks at the next party I attend.
Do you feel confident about stopping completely at the next gathering?
Yes, my friends aren't pressuring me much, so I can just say no to a drink if needed.
What benefits do you anticipate from achieving this goal?
I'll be more aware and alert, and it's better for my health since alcohol isn’t good for you.
It seems like you're comfortable with the idea of not drinking at your next party. Would it be okay if we meet again to check on how things are going?
Yes, that would be fine.
Great. Some benefits you mentioned include health improvements and better focus on academic goals. Is there anything else important for me to know?
How can I encourage my friends to stop drinking?

That's a great question. It can be challenging if your friends continue drinking, so one strategy is to engage in more activities that don't involve alcohol. If you're at a party, carrying an empty drink or something non-alcoholic might help deter others from offering you drinks. How do these suggestions sound?
That sounds helpful.
And how about discussing your decision with your friends—have you thought about how to approach them?
I plan on just telling them that I don't want to drink anymore.
It seems like your closest friends would be supportive of this. Do you have any other concerns or questions for me today?
No, I think I'm good.
Alright. Let's aim to meet in a few weeks to see how things are progressing. If everything is going well, that’s great; if not, we can work through any challenges together. Does that sound okay?
Yes, thank you.
You're welcome. I look forward to our next meeting.
Thank you too.
I hear that your asthma symptoms have been quite overwhelming. Let's explore some strategies to help you regain control and avoid needing further visits.
Yes, absolutely. I definitely don't want to come back here. But the doctor mentioned Oscar, my dog, is linked to my asthma issues. However—
I see.
—the strange thing is that he's been with me for 12 years without any problems until now.
It sounds like this news was unexpected for you. You must have seen the clinic materials about managing asthma and how pets can contribute to symptoms, right?
Yes, but I—let me clarify—I've reviewed those materials; I even read them. My main action has been taking my medication. So, I'm not very knowledgeable on this topic.
Hold on a moment, Sal. When you say you're uninformed, do you mean that despite knowing the importance of being informed—especially since your chart indicates you have a young baby—
Yes.
—a new addition to your family—and considering how much you care about staying healthy for them and having already made significant changes like nearly quitting smoking—
Mm-hmm.
—the next step is addressing the situation with Oscar. I know it's challenging, but there are always people willing to adopt pets. Perhaps friends or family could help?
This feels overwhelming right now. John Carlo is taken care of; he doesn't have asthma from the dog. It’s just me who—

My concern is for you, Sal. Your symptoms have worsened significantly, and you've experienced several severe asthma attacks. Do you realize that this poses a serious risk to your life? Some adults with severe asthma can face fatal outcomes due to their condition. This is something we must take very seriously.
So, Oscar could be the cause of my death? He hasn't caused any issues in 12 years, and the doctor suggests it might be stress or other factors. Why are we now saying Oscar could be life-threatening?

Sal, you understand that your asthma has been progressively worsening over time. The increasing strength of your medication indicates this progression. There's a limit to what medication can achieve alone.
They can continue prescribing stronger medications and give me the most potent one, but I'll keep Oscar.

You're nearing the strongest medication available. If Oscar is that important to you, do you value him more than your baby or wife? That doesn't make sense to me. Do you grasp how crucial this situation is?
I understand, but it seems like you don’t fully comprehend my circumstances. I've had Oscar for 12 years; I can't just remove him from my home without certainty that he's the main issue.
Okay, let’s see what we can do next.
Alright, David. How are you feeling after that rinse?
I'm feeling pretty good.
Would you like to take a look at how it turned out?
Sure, let's check it out.
What do you think of the results?
That looks really well done.
Yes, indeed.
You managed to get rid of that unsightly discoloration.
Absolutely. I noticed quite a bit of staining earlier. Do you have any thoughts on what might be causing it?
Well, the usual culprits like smoking, wine, and coffee are probably to blame.
Have you considered quitting smoking at this time?
Yes, I've thought about it. It's just not something that comes easily for me—I've tried before without success. Everyone keeps telling me to quit.
So, here I am as another person advising you to quit smoking, David.
Yeah, yeah, I know. [unintelligible 00:01:13] Hmm.
I apologize if it seems like I'm just adding to the chorus of voices telling you to quit.
I understand that smokers often hear "How can you smoke today?" [coughs] It's not easy to quit, though.
If quitting were as simple as some people suggest—
Yeah.
—like your doctor or partner says—
Well, who wouldn't want to quit if it was that straightforward?
Yes, it would be hard to ignore such advice.
I just hear it every day.
Can you share a bit about your history with smoking? How long have you smoked and what role does it play in your life?
I've been smoking for 40 years since I was 14. I quit a few times in my 20s, but it's been consistent ever since. Changing now seems unlikely.
It sounds like you've tried many methods without success.
Nothing has worked for me.
Yes, that must be frustrating.
I know cold turkey is probably the only way to quit for most people who've done it. My group did it that way—
Mm-hmm.
—but they struggled with it. It's my choice, and I don't appreciate lectures about it.
Yes, it truly is your decision. Nobody has the right to dictate what you should do. If there were a situation where you decided to quit, what would that look like?
That's hard to say because even open-heart surgery didn't make me quit. Prostate cancer didn't either. I just don't feel motivated.
So this is something you see yourself doing in the future?
Yes, it will take a while, quite a while.

Thank you for sharing that with me. Right now, quitting isn't on your agenda, but would it be okay if we revisit this topic next time? I understand you don't want lectures, yet I am concerned about your health.
Sure, I'm open to listening as long as there's no lengthy lecture.
As long as I keep it brief?
[laughs] Yes.
Okay. [chuckles]
My surgeon once asked why he should continue treating me.
Hmm.
He’s a great doctor, though. [laughs]
[chuckles] So you're glad to keep him as your doctor?
Yes.
David, wherever you are in this process, we'll work with it.
Okay.
Thank you for taking the time to talk about smoking today.
Thanks, doc.
Alright.
Okay.
Barbara Roberts?
Yes. Good morning.
Hello, there.
Hello.
I'm Dr. Betty, one of the new GPs here. May I know how you'd like me to address you?
You can call me Barbara. That's fine with me. Thank you.
Alright, that works for me. So, Barbara, it seems Dr. Brown usually sees you—is that correct?
Yes, Dr. Brown is my doctor.
Understood. What brings you to see me today?
I'm here about a stomach issue. It's been troublesome, and Dr. Brown hasn't found the cause yet. I thought maybe you could offer some help.
Alright. Could you tell me more about your stomach issues?

Sure. I experience discomfort almost all the time, often feeling bloated. My symptoms vary between constipation and diarrhea, with cramping or sharp pains at times. There's also a frequent urge to use the bathroom, accompanied by smelly gas.
It sounds like you're dealing with quite a few challenging symptoms.
Yes.
How long have these issues been occurring?
I think it started about four years ago after a holiday in Egypt where I had severe sickness and diarrhea. My stomach hasn't felt right since then.
So you believe the problem began around four years ago following that trip?
Yes, that's correct.
What treatments have you tried so far?
Dr. Brown initially prescribed muscle relaxants. I've also visited a health shop where they provided various tablets and medicines, including Immodium, which I always carry with me.
And how do you decide when to take these different remedies from the herbal shop?
Well, since my symptoms vary daily, I choose specific tablets based on what's bothering me at the time.
So it sounds like you're selecting treatments day by day depending on your symptoms. Is that right?
Yes.
Have any tests been conducted for these issues?
Yes, initially I had a gastroscopy and a barium enema, but Dr. Brown hasn't pursued further testing since they found nothing.
It seems you're not satisfied with the lack of additional tests.
Well, it feels like the NHS might be cutting costs, so he's decided I've had enough tests.
So you feel that more tests could have been done if resources allowed?
Yes, there are many tests available online that he hasn't considered. If I had more money, I'd go private.
It sounds like you believe not enough testing has been done. Is that correct?
Exactly. There's a lot more that could be explored.
So, to summarize, these stomach problems have persisted for about four years with various symptoms and treatments tried, but you feel the investigations haven't been thorough enough. Is that right?
Yes, that's accurate.
How has this situation impacted your daily life?

It's had a significant impact. I've reduced my work hours because sitting all day became uncomfortable, and eventually stopped working altogether about a year ago. I miss socializing with colleagues and friends.
It sounds like these symptoms have led to some major lifestyle changes for you.
Yes, they really have.
What do your days typically look like now?
I mostly stay at home, doing household chores and watching a lot of daytime TV. Sometimes I read magazines, but generally, I'm just at home.
Have there been any periods when your symptoms improved noticeably?
Last year, during my son's wedding preparations, I felt surprisingly well despite initial worries about managing it all.
How were your stomach symptoms then?
They hardly bothered me. It was a good time for me.
Are there times when the symptoms seem worse or more bothersome?
Currently, I'm in a rough patch with increased discomfort. It's particularly bad when my husband is away due to his job.
So you notice your symptoms worsen when he's not around. Is that correct?
Yes, maybe because I focus on them more when he's gone.
You've been consulting Dr. Brown for a few years now. What has he suggested might be the issue?
He thinks it's stress-related and all in my head.
And what are your thoughts on that?
I don't believe it can all be psychological because of the physical pain I experience.
Have you considered any possible causes yourself?

Initially, I thought it might have been an unresolved infection. Sometimes I wonder if it could be IBS or even an ulcer. On bad days, I worry about cancer due to my mother-in-law's experience with a late-diagnosed growth.
So you're concerned there might be something serious like cancer?
Yes, and at night, I often check for any changes in my stomach area just to be sure.

To ensure we understand correctly, you've seen Dr. Brown for several years, tried various medications with little success, undergone some tests but feel they were insufficient, and sometimes worry about the possibility of cancer. Is that right?
Yes, that's correct.
What are your hopes for today's visit with me?
I thought you might suggest new tests or treatments since you've just completed your medical training.
You were hoping I'd recommend additional tests?
Yes. There must be something a test could reveal.

Barbara, after hearing your story and symptoms, I'm not convinced that more tests would be beneficial at this point. The main investigations have already been done without significant findings, so it's unlikely they would show anything new now. It might be a waste of time to pursue further testing.
So do you think it's all in my head like Dr. Brown suggests?
No, I don't believe that at all. You clearly experience real pain and physical symptoms that significantly affect your life.

Sometimes these issues aren't just mental or physical; they can be interconnected. For instance, you mentioned feeling better during busy times, like your son's wedding, and worse when your husband is away. Could there be a connection between your emotional state, life circumstances, and how much your symptoms bother you?
I don't see my mind causing this level of pain.

I'm not suggesting the pain is in your mind. Rather, our emotions and life situations can influence how we perceive physical symptoms. Since medications and tests haven't helped much, perhaps it's time to explore a different approach.
What kind of approach are you thinking about?

Considering that your lifestyle has changed significantly over the past four years, with fewer enjoyable activities, I'm wondering if this might be affecting how you feel. Perhaps reintroducing some pleasurable activities could improve your overall well-being and even alleviate some symptoms.
I just can't do those things anymore.

It seems like dropping these activities was due to feeling unable to participate, but it's possible that not engaging in them has contributed to feelings of unhappiness, which might worsen your symptoms.
I'm not sure about that.

What if we focus on what you do with your time and try reintroducing some enjoyable activities? It could be as simple as meeting friends once a week. Additionally, reviewing the tablets you're taking to see which ones are helpful or potentially harmful might also be beneficial.
Hmm, I suppose that makes sense.
Would you consider trying this new approach for two or three months to see if it helps?
That's quite a long time if something serious is happening. My mother-in-law had a similar situation where they missed the signs.

If we decide to work together in this way, I'd schedule regular visits to monitor your symptoms. If anything changes, we can investigate further. But if things remain stable, it would confirm that there's nothing new to worry about. How does that sound?
That sounds reasonable.
Would you like to make an appointment for next week so we can discuss this approach in more detail and review your medications?
Yes, I'll schedule an appointment for next week to talk more about it.
Great. Please bring a list of the tablets you're taking when you come in. This will help us evaluate them together. Does that sound good?
Okay, I'll make a list instead of bringing all the bottles.
Perfect. Shall we see each other again next week then?
Yes, I'll book an appointment for next week.
Thank you, Barbara. See you soon.
Thank you. Goodbye.
Hi, Mary. How was your day?
Fine. Where do you want me to sign?
You can sign right there. It seems like today might not be a good time for conversation.
Not really.
I understand. It looks like you had a day at school and missed the first hour of class, is that correct?
Yeah, whatever. I just, yeah.
It sounds like missing class isn't particularly concerning to you right now?
It's just like the same thing every day; I don't really know why. So I signed your paper—why are you asking me all these questions?
You seem curious about what our visits are for and why I come to your house.
Yup.
Would it be okay if I explained again what this program is about?
I guess so.

My role as your caseworker involves checking in daily to ensure you're following the GPS requirements, that it's charged, and that you haven't left without permission. It also allows me to get to know you better during these visits.
So you just want to know my business?
I understand how it might seem intrusive at times.
